In compact numeric sensor, the `occurrenceRate` field doesn't mean update interval, it has the same mean as in numeric sensor's `unitRate` field which shouldn't be tied to the update time (this was verified by one of the DMTF members).

This is an issue because in this implementation sensors with `No Occurrence Rate` will not be updated at all.

Another issue is that the current pldm specs do not provide a way to determine the update time for compact numeric sensors.

Generally it isn't safe to pass references into co-routines because it is likely that the reference is invalidated before the co-routine even executes.  Are you sure this `&rcOpt` is safe?  I guess it is being stored in a ... map?  So it is probably safe, unless there is a possibility of the `stopPolling` being called prior to the co-routine completing.

Yes, `std::map` should store entries at stable address as part of its balanced tree implementation, so I'm pretty sure there is no problem.

`stopPolling` also makes sure to cancel `scope` before destroy the map entry. Given how `pldmd` runs single-threaded, I think cancellation will always happen first.

(Also, to destroy the map entry, according to `pair` layout, the map will need destroy the `scope` first, before destroying `rcOpt` and then destroying the entry. I have not check, but if `scope` RAII has already stopped the task, then `stopPolling` may not even need the `.request_stop()` part.)

As section 6.6.3/2 in the C++ standard

6.6.3 The return statement

2 A return statement without an expression can be used only in functions that do not return a value, that is, a function with the return type void, a constructor (12.1), or a destructor (12.4).
